Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Suprascapular and Interscalene Nerve Blocks in Shoulder Arthroscopy

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing shoulder arthroscopy, with eligibility criteria including the use of SSNB or ISB.

Intervention.evidence: This study aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of suprascapular nerve block (SSNB) versus interscalene brachial plexus block (ISB)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of suprascapular nerve block (SSNB) versus interscalene brachial plexus block (ISB)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain, measured using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at various time points.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment were adequately described in 15 and 16 studies, respectively.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding of outcome assessors was reported in all studies.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 1255 patients were randomised, with 17 RCTs analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: SSNB resulted in higher VAS at rest in PACU (MD = 0.56, 95% CI [0.19, 0.94], P = 0.003) but lower VAS at 12 hours post-operation (MD = −0.71, 95% CI [−1.12, −0.3], P = 0.0006).

Harms.evidence: SSNB had fewer complications, including Horner syndrome (P < 0.0001) and dyspnea (P = 0.04).
